page.title: 06The Origins of Rubery.
page.content: The earliest references to Rubery are to be found in 16th Century Deeds and plans, indicating the quarry ridge at the north-east end of the village as {"Roughberrow" (Rough Hill) or {Rowberrie. The small group of buildings a mile to the south-west was{"The Whetty",}and the area to the south at the foot of the Lickey Hills was described as the hamlet of{"Etchey"}or{Eachway. As each of the districts developed and merged, they became collectively grouped under one name as Rubery. The village itself is located in a saucer-shaped area overlooked on the south by the Waseley Hills, with ground on all sides sloping down towards the{Callow Brook}which starts in the Waseley Hills and flows through the middle of Rubery,then onwards to Birmingham.
